oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Salvage scrap drive in Nashville and Middle Tennessee region, 1942 October
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pictured: “Riding to Victory on a Water Tank: Little Floyd Edward Walker (center) age 3, although a “pre-schooler,” has joined his two older brothers, Buford Dean (left) and Jesse Lawrence (right), as top-notch scrap collectors in Jere Baxter School’s Junior Service Army, and goes along to supervise the collections. The Walker brothers are foregoing their afternoon playtime hours to hunt scrap in the neighborhood, and their little red wagon has a patriotic purpose to serve. No bolt is too small or any tank too large for the Walkers to collection for the Banner scrap drive and thus send their school closer to the Banner $2,000 War Bonds prizes, and the Allies to victory.” During World War II Americans were active with scrap drives to help the war effort. Local communities were salvaging raw materials such as metal, rags, rubber, and paper to be used to supply troops.
